data.title: 3.0 beta: Dual monitor use and 'walking' V-sync lin on screen
data.body:
Dear MonoGame developers.

I'm currently porting an existing XNA project to MonoGame. Most is running fine, my compliments for the ease of porting!.

Now I'm running into some small things, that may be related or not related, therefore I created separate 'issues' for these.

Platform is windows 7-64, VS express 2010 and the latest develop3d build for 3.0 Beta.

---

I have a framerate-counter running in the Draw() method, which tells me the amount of draws per second. 
When I run my application in  'graphics.IsFullScreen' set to 'false' and in non-airo mode, I get stable 60 FPS, the refresh rate of my monitor.

I'm intending dual-screen use, one screen for web-browsers and another applications, and one screen the MonoGame window.

Both screens run at 60Hz. 

Now if I run my application on one screen, the application runs smooth at 60FPS and no vertical line is visible anywhere.

When I move the MonoGame window to the other screen, there is now a 'walking' vertical line that runs about 1 time per second from the bottom of the screen to the top of the screen. ('tearing'?)

It seems the created window 'prefers' one screen as start for the refresh?

When using XNA 4.0 this issue is not there.

Running in Airo mode is currently not an option, since for me it generates half framerate (see issue #1067)

data.title: Fix minimizing Windows version
data.body:
To address issue #1056
The window state would be changed back to normal when the window was minimized due to the code in UpdateWindowState being run when it shouldn't have. OnResize was being called with a window client size of 1x1 when minimizing the window.  The fix is to early out if the new client size is 1x1 to prevent changing the back buffer to the new client size and incorrectly causing UpdateWindowState to bring the window back.

data.title: BlendState.Opaque + SpriteBatch not working
data.body:
Platform:WinRT

SpriteBatch doesn't respect the BlendState and draws everything with Alpha blending.
ex.
SpriteBatch.Begin(
               SpriteSortMode.Immediate,
               BlendState.Opaque,
               SamplerState.LinearClamp,
               stencilState, RasterizerState.CullNone
               );
After that SpriteBatch.Draw(...) should draw any texture opaque, whether or not the texture contains alpha channel.

---

UPDATE: I just realized that the problem was due to using PremultiplyAlpha (default) which changed the original picture and made it look as if it's blend with the background. 

Therefore there is no issue here. Feel free to close this.

data.title: GamePadState constructor with DPad state not respected in IsButtonDown

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
I'm using GamePadState constructor that takes in DPad state:

``` C#
public GamePadState(GamePadThumbSticks thumbSticks, GamePadTriggers triggers, GamePadButtons buttons, GamePadDPad dPad)
```

And later checking State.IsButtonDown(Buttons.DPadUp) expecting it to be true but it never is.

Looking at the GamePadState at this time I can see that its Buttons are all "Released" but its DPad.Up is pressed.

I expect State.IsButtonDown(Buttons.DPadUp) to be true in this case.

Looking at the exact same setup running against XNA for Windows Phone I can see my expected behavior is true, and the Buttons and DPad state are identical to MonoGame at this point.

This is also how XNA behaved on Windows.

So, IsButtonDown in XNA must be checking other internal state besides just Buttons such that it can handle DPad buttons correctly.

For some background, the game engine used for Taptitude has evolved over many years and has had a keyboard input mapper that acts like a gamepad for use on Windows.  This was mostly used for testing without  needing to plug a 360 controller in during XBLIG development a while back.  We haven't used it much since then as Taptitude has been a Windows Phone game without a need for keyboard support.

Now, we want to use the same keyboard mapper to simulate a gamepad for Windows 8 development as our UI system already supports navigation via GamePad (from our Xbox 360 days) and this would give us Keyboard navigation in Windows for free.

So while hooking the keyboard input mapper back up I noticed that the keyboard mapper no longer generated input events because we used IsButtonDown to see if a button had become pressed/released and under MonoGame it isn't detecting DPad button state.

I can certainly work around the issue on our end by explicitly checking the DPad state in certain cases but this is an incompatibility worth noting.

data.title: Touch positions are bogus on Windows Phone
data.body:
Using TouchPanel, the TouchLocation/Gesture X,Y positions are always float.Infinity. I have traced this in the code and observed the following:

1) The X,Y positions are correct when the XamlGame.OnPointerPressed() callback is handled.
2) TouchPanel.AddEvent() creates the TouchLocation, scaling the position by _touchScale, which is float.Inifity, resulting in the bogus position values.
3) _touchScale is infinity because in TouchPanel.ComputeTouchScale(), the scale is divided by Game.Instance.Window.ClientBounds (which currently set to 0,0).
4) Window.ClientBounds is 0,0 because WindowsPhoneGameWindow.SetClientBounds() is called while WPGameWindow.Height & .Width properties are both 0 (which they must be since SetClientBounds is called in the constructor).
5) The Height/Width properties are set (on every frame?) by XamlGame.PrepareResources(), but it's too late since SetClientBounds was already called in the WPGameWindow constructor.

I'm afraid I don't know the MonoGame codebase well enough yet to contribute a patch.

data.title: Graphics state objects appear mutable but are applied in an immutable fashion
data.body:
The graphics state objects, for example `RasterizerState` has mutable properties like `FillMode` etc but setting these properties has no effect as the `RasterizerState` property on the `GraphicsDevice` is only ever applied if the entire property is reassigned.   

Either that state change on the graphics state objects should propagate up to the `GraphicsDevice` to make its parent property dirty or the graphics state objects themselves are immutable objects i.e. no setters.

data.title: Performance Improvements for Touch Code
data.body: This commit exposes a new constructor for TouchCollection which just takes an IList<TouchLocation>. This lets you avoid having to instantiate a new array for every touch panel request. This improves performance by preventing the garbage collector from having to run as often.
